text: Using a human <extra_id_0> TSH receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TSH-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) cDNA probe , we investigated <extra_id_0> TSH-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcript levels in 13 human thyroid fragments by Northern blot analysis ; 7 Graves ' disease , 2 Hashimoto 's disease , 3 endemic goiter , and 1 healthy thyroid gland were studied .

<extra_id_0> TSH-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression levels were variable , but displayed a close correlation to the expression of <extra_id_0> thyroid peroxidase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( r = 0.703 ; P < 0.05 ) , <extra_id_0> thyroglobulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( r = 0.817 ; P < 0.01 ) , and the nuclear oncogene <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( r = 0.935 ; P < 0.001 ) , but not <extra_id_0> c-myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: Overall , <extra_id_0> TSH-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcript levels were low or absent in those thyroids in which expression of the major histocompatibility complex class I or II ( MHC I or II ) was high , thus establishing an inverse relation ( MHC I , r = -0.791 ; P < 0.01 ; MHC II , r = -0.784 ; P < 0.01 ) .
In situ hybridization showed that apart from lymphocytes , thyroid cells themselves were the source of MHC II transcripts .
<extra_id_0> gamma-Interferon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was only detectable in 1 Hashimoto 's goiter .

Our findings suggest that next to lymphocyte infiltration , active regulatory events in the thyrocyte are responsible for the inverse relation between functional parameters ( <extra_id_0> TSH-R <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> thyroid peroxidase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> thyroglobulin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and immunological markers ( MHC I and II ) .
